Definition of Shock.title: Definition of Shock
Definition of Shock.description:
Shock can be defined as a state of cellular and tissue hypoxia due to either reduced oxygen delivery, increased oxygen consumption or inadequate oxygen utilization.


The most common clinical manifestation of shock is hypotension, defined as a systolic blood pressure < 90 mmHg or mean arterial pressure < 65.

Basic Management of Cardiogenic Shock.title: Basic Management of Cardiogenic Shock
Basic Management of Cardiogenic Shock.description:
Patients who are at risk of developing CS or have clinical evidence of CS, the following sequential steps in management should be taken:

1. Characterization of the hemodynamic profile and volume status.
2. Determine the need for mechanical ventilator support.
3. Initiate pharmacologic therapy for hemodynamic support.
4. Determine the need for mechanical cardiocirculatory support.

explanation.title: Purge System
explanation.description:
• The purge system contains dextrose and UH (recommended 25 U/mL).• Placement of Impella requires also administration of systemic anticoagulation.
• Therefore, the total heparin delivered to the patient is equal to the heparin delivered through the purge system + systemic IV heparin.
• This needs to be taken into account when dosing systemic IV heparin.

explanation.title: Impella Positioning and Monitoring
explanation.description:
The right-side panel on the screen includes:
• Transthoracic echocardiography using the parasternal long-axis view can be used to monitor the Impella positioning in the ICU.
• Correct positioning occurs when the inlet area is located 3.5 cm from the aortic valve plane, at the middle of the LV cavity, with the distal tip of the pump oriented towards the LV apex, away from the papillary muscles.
• Correct positioning can also be monitored from the waveform on the monitor by assessing the placement signal.

explanation.title: Norepinephrine
explanation.description:
• Mechanism of action – Alpha more than beta agonist activity primarily leading to vasoconstriction.
• Indications – First Choice vasopressor.
• Dosing - 5 to 30 mcg/minute*, can go higher if there’s concomitant septic shock.

explanation.title: Epinephrine
explanation.description:
• Mechanism of action – More Beta than Alpha agonist activity translating to milder vasoconstriction and more potent inotropic effect compared to Norepinephrine.
• Indications – Additional vasopressor, Better at RV support.
• Dosing - 1 to 40 mcg/minute*.

explanation.title: Vasopressin
explanation.description:
• Mechanism of action – increase SVR and MAP through Arginine vasopressin receptor stimulation.
• Indications – adjunct vasopressor.
• Dosing – Fixed dose 0.03 unit/minute.

explanation.title: Dopamine
explanation.description:
• Mechanism of action – Dose dependent Renal and mesenteric vasodilation to cardiac stimulation.
• Indications – not the preferred initial agent in cardiogenic shock, bradyarrhythmia.
• Dosing - 0.5 to 20 mcg/kg/minute.

explanation.title: Dobutamine
explanation.description:
• Mechanism of action – stimulates Beta1 and some Alpha receptors leading to increased contractility and heart rate.
• Indications – Cardiogenic shock without significant hypotension, improves RV-PA coupling in RVMI.
• Dosing - 2 to 10 mcg/kg/minute for ionotropic support.

explanation.title: Milrinone
explanation.description:
• Mechanism of action – Inotropy and vasodilation through PDE inhibition.
• Indications – bridge advanced HF therapies or maintenance therapy in HFrEF.
• Dosing - 0.125 to 0.75 mcg/kg/minute.

*Calculated and rounded for an 80 kg patient based on weight-based dosing.

explanation.title: Diagnosis and Characterization of the Types of Shock Syndromes
explanation.description:
• The major determinant of tissue perfusion (and systemic blood pressure [BP]) are cardiac output (CO) and systemic vascular resistance (SVR).
• BP = CO x SVR.
• Where CO = Heart Rate (HR) x Stroke Volume (SV).
• Stroke volume is determined by: Preload Myocardial contractility Afterload.
• Biologic processes than can change any of this physiological variables can result in hypotension and shock.
• Serum lactate levels are used as surrogates for hypoperfusion and tissue hypoxia.

• Myocardial infarction.
• Acute decompensated heart failure.
• Myocarditis / Cardiomyopathy.
• Arrhythmias (Bradyarrhythmias or Tachyarrhthmias).
• Valvular heart disease (Acute severe valvular insufficiency, papillary or chordae tendineae rupture, valvular abscess; critical valvular stenosis).
• Mechanical complications of acute myocardial infarction.

explanation.title: Septic
explanation.description:
• Bacterial.
• Fungal.
• Viral.
• Parasitic.

explanation.title: Non - Septic
explanation.description:
• Inflammatory shock (e.g. burns, trauma, pancreatitis, cytokine release syndrome).
• Anaphylactic Shock.
• Neurogenic Shock.
• Acute liver failure.
• Vasoplegia (e.g. post-cardiopulmonary bypass).

• Pulmonary Embolism.
• Severe pulmonary hypertension.
• Tension pneumothorax.
• Pericardial tamponade.
• Left ventricular or right ventricular outflow track obstruction.

explanation.title: Hemorrhagic
explanation.description:
• Hypovolemic Shock.
• Trauma.
• Procedure-related complications.

explanation.title: Non -Hemorrhagic
explanation.description:
• Gastrointestinal losses.
• Skin losses.
• Renal losses.
• Third space losses into the extravascular space or body cavities.

explanation.title: Cardiogenic Shock
explanation.description: cardiogenic shock is due to intracardiac causes of cardiac pump failure that result in reduced cardiac output and end-organ failure.

explanation.title: Vasodilatory or Distributive Shock
explanation.description: Distributive shock is characterized by severe and dysregulated peripheral vasodilatation

explanation.title: Hypovolemic Shock
explanation.description: Hypovolemic shock is due to reduced intravascular volume (i.e., reduced preload) with subsequent reduction in cardiac output.

explanation.title: Obstructive Shock
explanation.description: Obstructive shock is due to extra-cardiac causes of cardiac pump failure with subsequent reduced end-organ perfusion.

nextOptions.description: Not Currently experiencing signs or symptoms pf CS, but at risk for its development

explanation.title: Physical Exam
explanation.description: • Normal JVP.• Warm and well- perfused.• Strong distal pulses.• Normal mentation.• Clear lung sounds.

explanation.title: Biochemical Markers
explanation.description: • Normal lactate.• Normal (or at baseline) renal function.

explanation.title: Hemodynamics
explanation.description: • SBP >100mmHg (or at baseline).• CI >2.5 (if acute).• CVP 65%.

nextOptions.title: (B) Beginning CS
nextOptions.description: Clinical evidence of hemodynamic instability without hypoperfusion

explanation.title: Physical Exam
explanation.description: • Normal JVP.• Warm and well- perfused.• Strong distal pulses.• Normal mentation.• Rales in lung fields.

explanation.title: Biochemical Markers
explanation.description: • Normal lactate.• Minimal acute renal function impairment.• Elevated BNP.

explanation.title: Hemodynamics
explanation.description: • SBP <90mmHg, or MAP <60mmHg, or > 30mm drop from baseline.• HR >100bpm.

nextOptions.title: (C) Classic CS
nextOptions.description: Hypoperfusion requiring intervention (pharmacologic or mechanical) beyond volume resuscitation

explanation.title: Physical Exam
explanation.description: • Volume overload.• Altered mental status.• Cold and clammy.• Extensive rales.• Urine output<30mL/h.

explanation.title: Biochemical Markers
explanation.description: • Lactate>2.• CR 1.5 x baseline or> 50% drop in GFR.• Increased LFTs.• Elevated BNP.

explanation.title: Hemodynamics
explanation.description: • CL<2.2 (if invasive hemodynamics performed [Strongly recommended] ).• r PCWP >15.

nextOptions.title: (D) Deteriorating
nextOptions.description: Failure of initial support strategy to restore perfusion

explanation.title: Physical Exam
explanation.description: • Any of stage C and worsening (or not improving) signs/sx of hypoperfusion despite initial therapy.

explanation.title: Biochemical Markers
explanation.description: • Any of stage C and lactate rising and persistently >2.• Deteriorating renal function.• Worsening LFTs.• Rising BNP.

explanation.title: Hemodynamics
explanation.description: • Any of stage C and requiring escalating doses or increasing numbers of pressors or addition of MCS device to maintain perfusion.

explanation.title: Physical Exam
explanation.description: • Typically unconscious.• Near pulselessness.• Cardiac collapse.• Multiple defibrillations.

explanation.title: Biochemical Markers
explanation.description: • Lactate >8.• CPR.• Severe acidosis (pH <7.2).

explanation.title: Hemodynamics
explanation.description: • Profound hypotension despite maximal.• hemodynamic support.• Need for bolus doses of vasopressors.
